questions.text: A biopsy done for a chronic verrucous lesion over the right cheek in an elderly man revealed the given histopathological finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The given image shows keratin pearls which are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized by the proliferation of atypical squamous cells with horn pearls/keratin pearls.

questions.text: During rounds, you have been asked to examine a patient with an ulcer over the face. Which of the following features will raise the suspicion of it being squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
On examination of an ulcer, everted margins will be suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).

SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. Variants of SCC in-situ include:

  • Bowen's disease
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Cautery ablation
  • Cryotherapy
  • Drug therapy including imiquimod
  • Moh’s microsurgery
  • Radiation therapy

questions.text:
Which of the following can increase the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma?
  1. Psoralen
  2. HPV 6 and 11
  3. Long-standing venous ulcers
  4. Bowen's disease
  5. Epidermolysis bullosa
questions.solution:
HPV 6 & 11 are not risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma, HPV 16 & 18 are risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma. 

Note: Skin cancer is the most frequent malignant neoplasm in organ transplant recipients, with SCC and BCC representing 95% of cancer.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma

  • UV exposure
  • Male sex- due to more sun exposure
  • Environmental factors-
    1. Psoralen and UVA (PUVA)
    2. Physical agents such as ionizing radiation
    3. Chemical agents such as arsenics
  • HPV-16 & 18
  • Immunosuppression 
  • Smoking
  • Chronic nonhealing wounds, burn scars, and chronic dermatosis
  • Hereditary conditions such as xeroderma pigmentosum, epidermolysis bullosa, and oculo-cutaneous albinism
  • Premalignant conditions like actinic keratosis, Bowen’s disease, erythroplasia of Queyrat

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding squamous cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Skin biopsy is mandatory in all cases
Mohs micrographic surgery is indicated for recurrent tumors
Broder's staging is based on the depth of the lesion
Lesion on the ear is a high-risk feature

questions.solution:
Broder's staging for SCC is based on histological grading. Depth or size of the tumor and lymph node involvement are not included in Broder's staging.

A skin biopsy is mandatory in all patients with suspected squamous cell carcinoma. Mohs micrographic surgery is indicated in patients with aggressive and high-risk SCC.

High-risk features of SCC include:

  1. Perineural invasion
  2. Depth of lesion greater than 2 mm
  3. Lesions on the ear 
  4. Poorly differentiated lesions

Note: Mohs micrographic surgery is the treatment of choice in BCC.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old farmer presented with a slow-growing lesion over his left hand for the past 5 months. The lesion was initially nodular, which then ulcerated. On examination, a 2 x 1 cm ulcer with everted margins was noted. Biopsy revealed keratin pearls. Which of the following stains will be positive for this condition?
  1. BCL2
  2. Cytokeratin 1
  3. CK-20
  4. HMB-45
  5. Cytokeratin 10
questions.solution:
SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinizing cells of the epidermis arising from the stratum germinatum (basalis) and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10.

CK-20 is specific for Merkel cell carcinoma. BCL2 is used to distinguish between basal cell carcinomas and trichoepitheliomas. HMB-45 is used to detect melanocytes.

questions.text: A 75-year old man came with complaints of a painless nodule on the left palm for the past 4 weeks. He gave a history of sustaining a thorn prick injury to the palm 5 weeks ago. On examination, the lesion appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing an exophytic nodule with central keratinous debris is suggestive of keratoacanthoma.

Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma. It presents clinically as a proliferating dome-shaped keratin-filled crater. Patients usually give a prior history of minor trauma. Treatment of choice is an excisional procedure with 4 mm margins.

Option A: Actinic keratoses consist of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the sun-exposed skin. They arise in middle-aged to older adults and have some potential for malignant transformation.

Option B: Bowen's disease appears histologically as SCC in situ. It initially presents with a red­dened area that progresses to thickened plaques and may vary from small lesions (<1 cm) to large areas. When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen disease is sometimes referred to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat.

Option D: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T cell lymphoma, and plaque-stage lesions are seen.

questions.text: A firefighter presented with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his left leg. He gave a history of sustaining  2nd-degree burns injury to the leg 10 years back during a rescue mission. The examination finding is as shown below. All of the following are true about this condition, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing an irregular ulcer with cauliflower shaped granulation tissue points to a diagnosis of Marjolin’s ulcer. It is avascular.

Related Pearl: Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low-grade squamous cell carcinoma arising from:
    1. Long-standing ulcers like a venous ulcer
    2. Post-burn scar
    3. Chronic osteomyelitis
    4. Post-radiation ulcer
  • Slow growing since it is relatively avascular
  • Painless due to the absence of nerves in scar tissue
  • No secondary deposits since there are no lymphatics in scar tissue
  • Radioresistant due to avascularity

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an epithelial tumor arising from basal cells. It is the most common type of skin cancer most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation (strongest risk factor), age 40-80 years with excessive sun exposure, light-skinned people, and exposure to arsenic compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light. It is more common in males than females. It is also associated with syndromes such as xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's syndrome.

Features of BCC include:

  • Pearly nodule with rolled border
  • Tortuous telangiectatic vessels 
  • Surface which can get ulcerated with raised and beaded edge, often with a central depression or umbilication
  • Bleeding on minor trauma

BCC has various subtypes such as nodular (most common type), pigmented, nodulocystic, morphoeic, infiltrative, and fibroepithelioma of Pinkus. 

It is locally aggressive and can erode the bone or facial sinuses. It rarely metastasizes via lymph nodes.

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

Depending upon the type of the lesion, a shave, punch or excisional biopsy may be employed for diagnosis. X-ray or CT may be needed if there is a local invasion. Histology shows peripheral palisading of cells.

Treatment: 

  • Surgical: Wide excision (4-6 mm clearance) with a skin graft or flap or primary suturing 
  • Mohs' surgery for BCC close to the eyes, nose, or ear to preserve more tissue.
  • Non-surgical: Radiotherapy, vismodegib and sonedegib.

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatofibrosarcoma, also known as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, slow-growing, well-differentiated primary fibrosarcoma of the skin, associated with increased production of platelet-derived growth factor-beta. It presents as a protuberant nodule within a firm, indurated plaque that can ulcerate. They are locally aggressive tumors with high recurrence rates. Treatment is wide excision and Mohs microscopic surgery. Imatinib is used for unresectable, metastatic, and recurrent tumors. The given image below shows a DFSP near the umbilicus.

 

Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a painless, slow-growing, locally malignant, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in a chronic scar (burns scar, scar of venous ulcer). It presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis. The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis. Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done. The given image below shows a marjolin's ulcer of the leg.

Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused due to mutations in the components of the RAS signaling pathway. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. The given image below shows a patient with multiple dysplastic nevi.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding basal cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Nodular is the most common type
Most commonly seen over the neck
Only punch biopsy is used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The most common form of BCC (60%) is the nodular variant. 

Other types of BCC are:

  • Superficial BCC- typically appears on the trunk as a pink or erythematous plaque with a thin pearly border
  • Infiltrative BCC
  • Pigmented variant of nodular BCC
  • Morpheaform variant - is an uncommon variant and is the most aggressive form
  • Fibroepithelioma of Pinkus

Option B: Patients with BCC show excellent prognosis with 100% survival rates for cases that have not spread to other sites.

Option C: Most of the basal cell carcinoma occurs on the face above the line joining the corner of the mouth and lobule of the ear.

Option D: Depending upon the type of lesion, a shave, punch, or exicision biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

The below image shows a nodular BCC

questions.text: Lymph node involvement may be seen in patients with all of the following cutaneous malignancies except?
questions.solution: Basal cell carcinoma does not show lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis. It is locally invasive.

questions.text: A construction worker presented to the clinic with a slowly enlarging lesion near the left inner canthus for the past 2 years. He noticed bleeding from the lesion for the past 2 months. On examination, a 3 x 1 cm ulcer with pearly rolled-out margins was noted.  A biopsy was done. Which of the following is the characteristic finding that will be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The characteristic finding of basal cell carcinoma is of ovoid cells in nests with a single 'palisading' layer.

The cells of a BCC resemble those of the basal layer of the epidermis. They are basophilic, have a large nucleus, and appear to form a basal layer by forming an orderly line around the periphery of tumor nests in the dermis, a feature referred to as palisading.

questions.text:
In patients with BCC, Mohs microscopic surgery will be indicated for which of the following features of the tumor?
  1. Recurrent tumor
  2. Tumor 1 cm in diameter
  3. Well differentiated tumor
  4. Tumor with perineural invasion
  5. Tumor involving the lip
questions.solution:
Moh’s microscopic surgery is indicated in patients with the following features of BCC:

  1. Primary lesions of the ear or lip
  2. Recurrent lesions
  3. With perineural invasion
  4. Poorly differentiated lesions
  5. Tumors more than 2 cm in size 

Moh’s microscopic surgery involves initial surgical excision of the tumor, followed by repeated tissue sampling along lateral and deep margins. These tissue samples are examined immediately under a frozen section for evidence of tumor. This process is repeated until the clearance is finally obtained.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with Gorlin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Osteoma is not a part of Gorlin syndrome.

Gorlin syndrome/basal cell naevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in the PTCH gene.

Components of Gorlin syndrome include:

  • Basal cell carcinomas
  • Medulloblastoma
  • Bifid ribs
  • Odontogenic keratocysts

questions.text: ABCDE rule applies for:
questions.solution:
ABCDE algorithm is used to diagnose melanoma.

It comprises of:

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variegation
  • Diameter of more than 6 mm 
  • Evolution or change


Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it represents only 4% of skin cancers, it accounts for 80% of deaths (high mortality rate). It presents as a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled.

Histopathological confirmation is the gold standard in the diagnosis of melanoma. It is divided into four main types: nodular melanoma (NM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). 

The treatment consists of wide local excision of the tumor and follow-up to detect any local recurrence around the scar and excluding nodal spread.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

  • Thickness (Breslow index)***
  • Sentinel node status***
  • Ulceration**
  • Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)
  • Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)
  • Age* (negative for older age)
  • Sex* (negative for males)
  • Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: An anxious patient with a black mole over his back presents to the clinic for evaluation. All of the following features according to the ABCDE rule will point towards a diagnosis of melanoma in this patient except?
questions.solution:
D stands for diameter >6 mm and not depth > 6mm.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding malignant melanoma?

choices.text: Lentigo maligna type has the worst prognosis
Acral melanoma is the most common type in dark-skinned individuals

questions.solution:
Lentigo maligna melanoma has the best prognosis. Nodular melanoma has the worst prognosis. 

Option B: Malignant melanoma arises from melanocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction (junctional melanocytes). They may also arise from mucosal surfaces of the eyes, pharynx, esophagus, anorectal and genital areas. 

Option C: Malignant melanoma most commonly metastasizes to the lungs. 

Option D: Acral melanoma is the most common type in dark-skinned individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of malignant melanoma?
questions.solution:
Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common type of malignant melanoma. It usually arises in a pre-existent naevus.

Other types of malignant melanoma include:

  • Nodular melanoma - presents as a nodule, and has the worst prognosis. 
  • Acral lentiginous melanoma - commonly seen over palms and soles. Most common melanoma in dark-skinned individuals.
  • Lentigo maligna melanoma - also known as Hutchinson's melanotic freckle. More commonly seen on sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, or hands of the elderly. It is the least common and has the best prognosis.

questions.text: What does the finding depicted in the image signify?
questions.solution:
The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in subungual melanoma. It arises from the nail matrix, most commonly in the great toe or thumb.

Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clinical clue to subungual melanoma. It is characterized by the extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. It is also associated with nail dystrophy. 

Note: Pseudo-Hutchison’s sign is a reflection of the pigmentation of the nail bed and nail matrix through the transparent nail folds. 

Option A: Subungal hematoma is a close differential of subungual melanoma. It is seen secondary to trauma which causes bleeding and resultant hematoma formation and pigmentation. It is important to note that the features of Hutchinson's nail sign are not seen with subungual hematoma.

Option B: Nodular melanoma is a condition where malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth. The lesion presents as a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging.

Option D: Lentigo maligna is an early form of melanoma, in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as in-situ melanoma.

Note: Subungual melanoma can be either superficial spreading melanoma or acral lentiginous melanoma. A difference of opinion has been noted in Bailey and Love, 27th ed. where it has been mentioned that melanoma under the fingernail is usually superficial spreading melanoma. However, most dermatology textbooks including the Rooks 9th ed. and Fitzpatrick's 9th ed and several research articles mentioned subungual melanoma as a variant of acral lentiginous melanoma.

questions.text: Most common site of lentigo maligna melanoma is ______
questions.solution: Lentigo maligna melanoma also known as Hutchison’s melanotic freckle is more commonly seen on sun-exposed areas like face, neck or hands of the elderly. It is the least common and least malignant type.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used for staging patients with melanoma?
  1. Breslow
  2. Van-Nyus
  3. Clark's 
  4. Atlanta 
  5. Onodera's
questions.solution:
Both Breslow and Clark’s system is used for melanoma staging. 

Breslow thickness is the depth of invasion measured from the granular layer of the epidermis to the base of the lesion. As the thickness of the melanoma increases, the prognosis worsens. Clark's is based on the layer of skin to which melanoma has invaded. 

Breslow thickness has largely supplanted Clark's as it is a more accurate method of predicting prognosis.

Van-nyus prognostic index is used for DCIS.

Atlanta's is used for acute pancreatitis.

Onodera's prognostic index is used for hepatocellular carcinoma after initial hepatectomy 

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

Related Pearl: Clark’s Classification

Level

questions.text: A farmer presented with a brownish lesion over the plantar aspect of the left foot for 2 years. Over the last few months, he noticed that the lesion was increasing in size. On examination, a 2 x 1.5cm asymmetric lesion with notched edges was noted. Excision biopsy revealed cells containing large, pleomorphic nuclei and numerous mitotic figures. Which of the following will be used as a marker for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history and biopsy finding is suggestive of melanoma. S-100 is a marker for melanoma.

Other markers for melanoma are:

  • MELAN-A
  • HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45
  • LDH

questions.text: Which of the following will be the most important prognostic indicator in patients with stage 1 melanoma?
questions.solution:
The best prognostic factor in primary stage 1 melanoma (T1N0) is the tumor thickness or depth of the melanoma. 

The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index for melanoma in general. But in Stage 1 melanoma, as there is no lymph node involvement, the depth of the melanoma is the best prognostic factor.

 Other major prognostic factors, in order of impact on survival, include:

  • Presence of lymph node metastases
  • Ulceration
  • Age
  • Anatomic location of the primary tumor 
  • Gender

questions.text:
Arrange the types of melanoma from best to worst according to their prognosis?
  1. Lentigo maligna melanoma
  2. Nodular melanoma
  3. Superficial spreading melanoma
  4. Acral lentiginous melanoma
questions.solution:
The order of prognosis for types of melanoma from better to worse is: 

Lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) > superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) > nodular melanoma (NM)

The LMM and ALM both have long horizontal phases. As a result of this, there will be more time to detect them before they enter the vertical phase of growth. Thus LMM and ALM have a better prognosis than other subtypes.

The SSM has an intermediate prognosis, as the horizontal phase is rapidly followed by the vertical phase.

The NM has the worst prognosis, as there is no horizontal phase and it starts with a vertical growth phase. This leads to a greater average tumor thickness.

questions.text:
A patient presented from the dermatology out-patient with a biopsy-proven melanoma on her right arm with a Breslow depth of 2.1 mm. Nodes were clinically negative. What is the surgical management for this patient?

SLNB: Sentinal lymph node biopsy
questions.solution:
Wide local excision with a resection margin of 2 cm along with sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) will be recommended for melanomas invading to a depth > 2mm.

Recommended margins of wide local excision:

Depth Margin
In situ 0.5 cm
<1 mm 1 cm
1-2 mm 1-2 cm
>2-4 mm 2 cm
>4 mm 2 cm

Wide local excision with SLNB is preferred for early-stage tumours. SLNB should be performed for lesions >1mm in depth. If SLNB is positive or if nodes are clinically positive, lymph node dissection should be performed.

SLN biopsy is more challenging in the head and neck than in other regions because of the rich lymphatic drainage network, and the false-negative rate for SLN biopsy is generally higher for melanomas in these locations. Cross-sectional imaging, such as with a single-photon emission CT, helps to identify the exact anatomic location of the SLNs more accurately.

questions.text: Which of the following FDA-approved adjuvant therapy will be recommended for patients with malignant melanoma?
questions.solution:
The only systemic adjuvant therapy approved by the US FDA for malignant melanoma is high-dose interferon alpha 2b.

It is administered at nearly the maximum tolerated dose, with 1 month of intravenous injections followed by 11 months of subcutaneous injections three times weekly.

Note: Dabrafenib is a BRAF inhibitor used in advanced stages of melanoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding  Merkel cell carcinoma?

choices.text: Regional lymph nodes will be involved in 30% of the cases
It is characterized by a rapidly growing, flesh-colored papule
Wide local excision is usually done

questions.solution:
Recurrence is common in Merkel cell carcinoma.

Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin, most commonly found in white men and diagnosed at a mean age of 70 years. A rapidly growing, flesh-colored papule or plaque characterizes the disease. 

Regional lymph nodes are involved in 30% of the patients and 50% will develop systemic disease. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma. Wide local excision is usually necessary.

questions.text: A lady comes with a reddish firm nodule on her chest which hasn't grown in size. Its histolopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with reddish firm nodule on her chest and histology showing multiple dilated vascular structures with a single layer of epithelial cells is suggestive of a hemangioma.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are capillary hemangioma (most common), juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma, cavernous hemangioma and pyogenic hemangioma.

Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to a large hemangioma over the eyelid).

Treatment options include:

  • Beta-blockers - oral propranolol
  • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser

The given image shows a flat to elevated, irregular, pinkish-red mass over the skin of the abdomen suggestive of a strawberry hemangioma.

The given image shows a capillary hemangioma in a child

questions.text: Extra mammary Paget's disease is commonly seen in the:
questions.solution:
Extramammary Paget's disease arises most frequently on the vulva. Other sites include the perineum, scrotum, perianal skin, and penis.

Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) can be primary or secondary.

  • Primary EMPD is more common and occurs in the absence of an underlying malignancy, thought to arise from intraepidermal parts of apocrine glands or from pluripotent cells from the epidermis.
  • Secondary EMPD arises from an underlying adnexal carcinoma or internal malignancy due to the epidermotropic spread of malignant cells from the underlying tumor.

Visceral malignancies associated with EMPD are carcinomas of the colon, rectum, bladder, urethra, cervix, and prostate. The patient presents with well-defined, moist, erythematous scaly plaques and severe pruritis. Lichenification and excoriations may also be seen.

Diagnosis is confirmed by punch, wedge, or excisional skin biopsy. A systemic workup should also be done to identify any underlying malignancy and they include colonoscopy, cystoscopy, colposcopy, and pelvic examination with pap smear in females. 

Treatment: 

  • Mohs microscopic surgery with 5 cm margin clearance 
  • Radiotherapy 
  • Topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod 
  • Chemotherapy 
  • Photodynamic therapy 

The given image below shows extramammary Paget's disease of the vulva.

questions.text: A postmenopausal lady presented with an itchy plaque over the vulva for the past 2 years, which persisted despite multiple topical treatments. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells with mucin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and presence of large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells) points to a diagnosis of extramammary Paget's disease. It is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma.

Extramammary Paget's disease usually presents in the sixth to eighth decades of life. It may occur in the genital or perianal regions, or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the axilla. Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive neoplasm. 

It most commonly presents with pruritus. The clinical appearance is similar to mammary Paget's Disease. Scattered areas of erosion and white scale can give rise to a “strawberries and cream” appearance. The invasion of the lymphatic system by the tumor gives rise to underpants-pattern erythema. 

Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment.

The given image shows large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells)

questions.text:
In which of the following subtypes of soft tissue sarcoma is lymph node dissection mandatory?
  1. Clear cell sarcoma
  2. Liposarcoma
  3. Rhabdomyosarcoma
  4. Angiosarcoma
  5. Synovial sarcoma
questions.solution:
Most of the soft tissue sarcomas undergo hematogenous dissemination to metastasize to lungs, liver, bones, and subcutaneous tissue. Regional lymph node involvement is relatively uncommon. However, the most common subtypes with nodal metastasis are:

  • Clear cell sarcoma
  • Liposarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Epitheloid sarcoma
  • Malignant fibrous histiocytoma

Lymph node involvement is an important prognostic indicator for survival. Hence, lymph node dissection is mandatory in these cases.
